He who defines the terms controls the debate -- and by extension, public opinion.¬† On this issue the terms have been defined (in many cases invented) by the talented sophists of the ‚Äúgay‚Äù movement.¬† Sophistry, it must be noted, is the ancient Greek art of persuasion by subtly false reasoning.¬† The key to overcoming sophistry is to simplify and clarify what the sophists have intentionally made complex and vague.¬† That process begins by defining the terms and concepts being used in the arguments. One quickly discovers that most arguments advocating ‚Äúgay rights‚Äù depend upon hidden false assumptions and deliberately ambiguous terms.¬† It‚Äôs all smoke and mirrors.¬†¬†¬† ¬†

Among the most common terms and concepts in the ‚Äúgay rights‚Äù debate are: homosexuality, sexual orientation, heterosexism, diversity, multi-culturalism, inclusiveness, discrimination, homophobia and tolerance.¬† These words and phrases are used by ‚Äúgay‚Äù sophists to frame the question of homosexuality as a civil rights issue.¬† It is a context chosen to favor homosexuals to the extent that they cast themselves as victims and their opponents as oppressors, yet even within this context, ‚Äúgay‚Äù arguments are easily refuted

It is true homosexuality is not the norm, but it is natural in nature as is blue eyes, left-handed people, twin births, geniuses, etc.  Of course reproduction requires a man and a woman but reproduction is not the only reason for sexuality; just as our mouths are not only for eating but also for communicating. text:
Neither Christianity nor homosexuality is evil or hateful.  Forcing others to believe as you do, and discriminating against those who are different than yourself is BOTH evil and hateful. Honestly, the same goes for religion-haters who believe that all people who maintain religious beliefs are the cause of all the world's problems.  Religion (like politics) has undeniably been misused, but not by everyone who practices it.  Most practice it for their own spiritual development, and also to help provide support to those in need. Subclass: Presenting facts, Pointing out hypocrisy or contradictions, Denouncing hateful or dangerous speech
text:
This man is teaching the oldest trick, which is deception. He isn't preaching the love of God or Christ here. Pride, judgement, and fame may prove to be his worst friends. This is unfortunate to watch. Only those who are faultless have the right to pass judgment upon others. We must understand that the Bible is a book written by men, inspired by God. They were called ‚ÄúChristians‚Äù because their behavior, activity, and speech were to be like Christ Jesus. Even most who call themselves Christians today, fail to fit the definition. I know I do. Each day is a day to strive to be better. I'm thankful for God's love, and His grace. As we define the word Christian, it should lead us to teachings and words directly from Christ. In those truths, we find our flaws. I have 4 points that oppose the way this man leads. They are as follows:

*1- Define the word ‚ÄúChristian.‚Äù The word is only used 3 times in the New Testament and each instance is referring to the first ‚ÄúChristians‚Äù of the early church. The word Christian means, ‚Äúfollower of Christ‚Äù or ‚Äúbelonging to the party of Christ.‚Äù

    ‚Äú‚Ä¶So for a whole year Barnabas and Saul met with the church and taught great numbers of people. The disciples were called Christians first at Antioch‚Äù (Acts 11:26).

    ‚ÄúThen Agrippa said to Paul, ‚ÄòDo you think that in such a short time you can persuade me to be a Christian?‚Äô‚Äù (Acts 26:28).

    ‚ÄúHowever, if you suffer as a Christian, do not be ashamed, but praise God that you bear that name‚Äù (1 Peter 4:16).


*2- Evaluate what Jesus Christ identifies as the greatest two commandments.     

And one of the scribes came up and heard them disputing with one another, and seeing that he answered them well, asked him, ‚ÄúWhich commandment is the most important of all?‚Äù Jesus answered, ‚ÄúThe most important is, ‚ÄòHear, O Israel: The Lord our God, the Lord is one. And you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your mind and with all your strength.‚Äô The second is this: ‚ÄòYou shall love your neighbor as yourself.‚Äô There is no other commandment greater than these.‚Äù
    ‚Äî‚ÄâMark 12:28-31

     And behold, a lawyer stood up to put him to the test, saying, ‚ÄúTeacher, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?‚Äù He said to him, ‚ÄúWhat is written in the Law? How do you read it?‚Äù And he answered, ‚ÄúYou shall love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and with all your strength and with all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself.‚Äù And he said to him, ‚ÄúYou have answered correctly; do this, and you will live.
    ‚Äî‚ÄâLuke 10:25-28

     When he had gone out, Jesus said, ‚ÄúNow is the Son of Man glorified, and God is glorified in him. If God is glorified in him, God will also glorify him in himself, and glorify him at once. Little children, yet a little while I am with you. You will seek me, and just as I said to the Jews, so now I also say to you, ‚ÄòWhere I am going you cannot come.' A new commandment I give to you, that you love one another: just as I have loved you, you also are to love one another. By this all people will know that you are my disciples, if you have love for one another.‚Äù
    ‚Äî‚ÄâJohn 13:31-35


*3- Compare the speech & actions of this man & his views towards others, with the speech & actions of Jesus Christ about judging one another.     
John Chapter 8 - vs 1-12   King James Version

1Jesus went unto the mount of Olives. 2 And early in the morning he came again into the temple, and all the people came unto him; and he sat down, and taught them. 3 And the scribes and Pharisees brought unto him a woman taken in adultery; and when they had set her in the midst, 4 They say unto him, Master, this woman was taken in adultery, in the very act. 5 Now Moses in the law commanded us, that such should be stoned: but what sayest thou? 6 This they said, tempting him, that they might have to accuse him. But Jesus stooped down, and with his finger wrote on the ground, as though he heard them not. 7 So when they continued asking him, he lifted up himself, and said unto them, He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone at her. 8 And again he stooped down, and wrote on the ground. 9 And they which heard it, being convicted by their own conscience, went out one by one, beginning at the eldest, even unto the last: and Jesus was left alone, and the woman standing in the midst. 10 When Jesus had lifted up himself, and saw none but the woman, he said unto her, Woman, where are those thine accusers? hath no man condemned thee? 11 She said, No man, Lord. And Jesus said unto her, Neither do I condemn thee: go, and sin no more. 12 Then spake Jesus again unto them, saying, I am the light of the world: he that followeth me shall not walk in darkness, but shall have the light of life.

*4- Evaluate the books of Samuel. Read these books and learn some key things about David, the shepherd who later defeated Goliath. He was shown favor by King Saul, and lead many armies into battle with massive victories. He was also loved by, the son of King Saul, Jonathan. The Lord departed from King Saul, and sent an evil spirit to torment him. With this spirit, Saul would try to kill David, while David was playing soothing music for him. King Saul later verbally judged his own son Jonathan because of his love for David, and spoke future failure into him. The love of Jonathan for David saved David's life, and they kissed one another in a field while saying their last goodbye. They made an agreement that their relationship would always be known throughout future generations. King Saul would die after failing to commit suicide once in battle out of fear and pride. Jonathan would die in that same battle. When David heard of the deaths he mourned them both. "I am distressed for thee, my brother Jonathan: very pleasant hast thou been unto me: thy love to me was wonderful, passing the love of women," said King David. David would take the child of Jonathan a raise him. What can be debated is whether or not either of these men were what we call gay. What can never be debated, is that they both professed love for one another that neither felt that women gave them. And still, David had many wives, many children, even took a wife from another man that he felt should have been his first. David killed many in battle, and even had women and children killed in towns. But today we speak of the King David as one that was favored by God. And so I leave you with this. Of all the sins that this man did, how could he be used and blessed by God at all? The answer I have is a simple one. God is love. God is grace, that surpasses all understanding. God can use the sinner, of who we ALL are. And Jesus always pointed to God!!! Jesus even corrected a man who called him "Good," saying that ONLY GOD IS GOOD. 


My closing prayer:
"Thank You God for Your love, Your grace, and Your patience with us humans. May You have mercy on us for judging those sins that are less than that of a murderous heart. Thank You Jesus, for all that you have done to lead us the the way! To this I say AMEN."~Kevin Napier
